results.description: I'm a naturalist! I co-founded iNat, but I quit in 2025. You can keep up with what I'm doing on kueda.net, Mastodon, Bluesky, and yes, even Patreon. A little about me: I've been fascinated by nature for as long as I can recall. I used to horrify my mom by waltzing into the house holding snakes and salamanders to show her. Eventually, I translated that love into a degree in biology. Since then, I've worked as a GIS technician, web developer, and wildlife technician. iNaturalist grew out of the belief that I might not be alone in my desire to combine nature and the Web. iNat has rendered that belief unnecessary. If you'd like to learn more about the origins of iNat, check out this recording of a description I gave in 2013 (starts around 7:40). iNat started as a masters final project at the UC Berkeley School of Information, and they still host our slides and report from that project. If you want me to join your project, you'll have to describe to me what it does that can't be done at https://www.inaturalist.org/observations. If it's just another combination of place and taxon except with your logo on it, I'll pass. If you'd like me to check out an observation / journal post / whatever, please explain why and don't just @ mention me, e.g. "Hey @kueda, what do you think of this?" instead of just "@kueda." The latter makes me feel like some kind of pet or robot that you're summoning. If you want to use one of my photos in a publication, please abide by the license I have applied to it on iNat. If you're seeking my explicit permission to use my photo in a scientific publication, as of 2021 I will only grant it if your paper will be open access and free for anyone to read in its entirety because I think if you're going to use content that was given away freely to make something else, you should give away the thing you made in the same spirit. And I just don't believe scientific information is property. I know not everyone can afford open access publication fees which is partly why I don't enact those beliefs in my license choices. For commercial field guides, please get in touch. Elsewhere: * BugGuide contributions * Moth Photographers Group photos (I don't have any control over these, I think they just pick stuff they want from BugGuide after obtaining the photographer's permission) * Tree of Life contributions * my field guides on Goodreads * my pitiful eBird profile page * Mastodon
results.name: Ken-ichi Ueda
